description:
In Edo in the mid-1800's, fireworks maker Seikichi Tamaya and his friends struggle to live under the harsh morality laws imposed by the strict city councilor, which ban all luxuries, including fireworks. One day, a strange girl stops by Sekichi's shop with an equally strange request: she wants Sekichi to build a firework that can reach the moon.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Anachronism
tags.description: Prominently features elements that are out of place in the historical period the work takes place in, particularly modern elements in a historical setting.

tags.name: Shapeshifting
tags.description: Features character(s) who changes one's appearance or form.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Ninja
tags.description: Prominently features Japanese warriors traditionally trained in espionage, sabotage and assasination.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/marchimark) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/jamiemarchi/)

An American voice actress, ADR director, and script writer who works for Funimation and Sentai Filmworks. She grew up in Oklahoma and graduated from the University of Oklahoma with a bachelor's degree in theater, starting her professional acting career in 2000. She married fellow actor Sean T. Perez on August 8, 1999, and they divorced on November 21, 2005. Jamie has two step-daughters. Her younger half-brother, [Jean-Luc Hester](https://anilist.co/staff/104094), is also a voice actor.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kawasak54965532)

Hiroyuki Kawasaki is a screenwriter and novelist.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oichanmusi) | [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/profile/oichanmusi.bsky.social) | [Website](https://hifumi-inc.co.jp/team/mizushima-seiji/)

After graduating from Tokyo Designers' Gakuin College, Mizushima joined [Tokyo Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/899/). While doing photography work at the beginning of his career he studied under director of photography [Masahiro Kumagai](https://anilist.co/staff/174419/). He later went to work for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as a production assistant, aiming to become a full-fledged director.

Mizushima debuted as an episode director in 1993 on [Kouryuu Densetsu Villgust](https://anilist.co/anime/2049/), aiding the director of the OVA [Katsuhiko Nishijima](https://anilist.co/staff/103059/). In 1998, he made his proper directorial debut with [Generator Gawl](https://anilist.co/anime/1022/). He has since gone on to direct numerous shows, among which [Shaman King](https://anilist.co/anime/154/), [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/) and [Oh! Edo Rocket](https://anilist.co/anime/2152/).

He often cites [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) as an anime director that he respects.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oichanmusi) | [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/profile/oichanmusi.bsky.social) | [Website](https://hifumi-inc.co.jp/team/mizushima-seiji/)

After graduating from Tokyo Designers' Gakuin College, Mizushima joined [Tokyo Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/899/). While doing photography work at the beginning of his career he studied under director of photography [Masahiro Kumagai](https://anilist.co/staff/174419/). He later went to work for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as a production assistant, aiming to become a full-fledged director.

Mizushima debuted as an episode director in 1993 on [Kouryuu Densetsu Villgust](https://anilist.co/anime/2049/), aiding the director of the OVA [Katsuhiko Nishijima](https://anilist.co/staff/103059/). In 1998, he made his proper directorial debut with [Generator Gawl](https://anilist.co/anime/1022/). He has since gone on to direct numerous shows, among which [Shaman King](https://anilist.co/anime/154/), [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/) and [Oh! Edo Rocket](https://anilist.co/anime/2152/).

He often cites [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) as an anime director that he respects.

The founder and former representative director of [Funimation](https://anilist.co/studio/102/).

**Non-anime roles:**
- Policeman in "Chuck E. Cheese in the Galaxy 5000"

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/75655903) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/something_Yoshimatsu/)

Affiliated with Studio Live since 1982. Studied under [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/). He has deep ties into [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) ever since working as a character designer on [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/) in 1998. A member of the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA).

Works as a mangaka under the name Something Yoshimatsu (サムシング吉松).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/75655903) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/something_Yoshimatsu/)

He has deep ties into [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) ever since working as a character designer on [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/) in 1998. Works as a mangaka under the name Something Yoshimatsu (サムシング吉松).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/75655903) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/something_Yoshimatsu/)

Affiliated with Studio Live since 1982. Studied under [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/). He has deep ties into [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) ever since working as a character designer on [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/) in 1998. A member of the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA).

Works as a mangaka under the name Something Yoshimatsu (サムシング吉松).
Racehorse owner and son of the late [Atsushi Yamatoya](https://anilist.co/staff/200012).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/123099499)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/snjaramaki) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/荒牧伸志) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinji_Aramaki)

Aramaki is one of the leading figures in the industry's CG animation, and is noted for his various design works in numerous anime series such as [Gasaraki](https://anilist.co/anime/782/), [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/), [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/) and [Soul Eater](https://anilist.co/anime/3588/) among many others.

Influenced by [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/), and Star Wars during his junior and senior high school years, he decided to pursue a career in film. One of his first representative works was an independently produced animation titled "Moonstruck Artemis," that he made while part of a manga club during his university days. Aramaki didn't have a special desire to work in the animation industry, but has stated joining it solely because he could draw and the industry had a wide range of options for someone like that. He has also said that the spread of digital technology has made it easier for him to work in both anime and live-action.

In 2004, Aramaki directed [Appleseed](https://anilist.co/anime/54/), a re-interpretation of a [Shirou Masamune](https://anilist.co/staff/97609/) manga by [the same name](https://anilist.co/manga/30668/). Although bashed by critics, the movie was an influential piece in the medium that had great impact on creators around the world. Studio Ghibli co-founder [Toshio Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101638/) said the movie would reform the industry.

Originating from [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). Noted for his work on EDs, which he usually animates by himself. He often asks for [Yoshiyuki Takei](https://anilist.co/staff/150095/) to handle the photography work in them because of the trust he has in his compositing skills. Suzuki is also close friends with [Kumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/104698/) and participates in most of the shows in which she serves as a character designer.

Nowadays, he rarely puts his name on the telop and has gone uncredited for most of his work after [Soul Eater](https://anilist.co/anime/3588/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/64664693)

Yamamoto's interest in working in the anime industry piqued in high school after realizing how noticeable the difference in episodes were depending on the episode director in charge. One of his favourites shows included [Seisenshi Dunbine](https://anilist.co/anime/929/).

In the late '80s, he joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as a production assistant after finding out that it's how many of the studio's directors started off. There he met and studied under [Shuuji Iuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/115833/) on his shows [Madou King Granzort](https://anilist.co/anime/2818/) and [Mashin Eiyuuden Wataru](https://anilist.co/anime/4807/). Then after having gone freelance he got his first shot as a director as one of the three unit directors on Iuchi's [Ranma ½ film](https://anilist.co/anime/418/) in 1991.

In 2001, Yamamoto made his debut as a series director on [Shiawase Sou no Okojo-san](https://anilist.co/anime/2934/), soon after which he worked as the first director of the long-running [Keroro Gunsou](https://anilist.co/anime/516/). In 2006 he directed the well-received [NHK ni Youkoso!](https://anilist.co/anime/1210/)

More recent directorial works of his include [Yama no Susume](https://anilist.co/anime/14355/) and [Shounen Maid](https://anilist.co/anime/21321/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nabe_atsu_live)

Puffy (romanized as PUFFY in Japan) or Puffy AmiYumi is a Japanese rock duo that is currently signed with Sony Music Japan. The group continues to go by the moniker of PUFFY in Japan, but in order to avoid legal naming conflicts with Sean Combs, it has adopted the name Puffy AmiYumi outside of Japan. They sing in Japanese and English.  [Ami Oonuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101448/), whose nickname is Jane, and [Yumi Yoshimura](https://anilist.co/staff/101449), nicknamed Sue, were scouted by Sony-affiliated talent agencies and put together in the mid-1990s. The band gained mainstream success in Japan during 1998, following the release of their Jet album and tour in support of it.  Their first release "Asia no Junshin" sold a million records and their success has continued with several more full-length releases (totaling 14 million sales in Japan).
Tyler Walker is an ADR Director, Script writer and voice actor for FUNimation.
